title: Can you transplant a head to another body? - Max G. Levy

options.label: A
options.text: The monkey died immediately after the surgery

options.label: C
options.text: The monkey survived and was able to see, smell, and hear

options.text: Whether the monkey would be paralyzed

options.label: C
options.text: Whether the monkey's brain would function normally after the surgery

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: It led to the development of new surgical instruments

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: How could so many people support Hitler? - Joseph Lacey

multiple-choice.question: What was Adolf Eichmann's role in the Nazi regime?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a high-ranking official responsible for planning the Holocaust.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a low-ranking officer responsible for the transport of European Jews to concentration camps.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a desk clerk responsible for organizing the logistics of the Nazi regime.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a German citizen who was not directly involved in the Nazi regime.

multiple-choice.question: What was Hannah Arendt's observation about Adolf Eichmann's nature?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a charismatic leader who inspired loyalty in his followers.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a sadistic killer who enjoyed causing pain and suffering.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a dull bureaucrat who seemed more interested in following rules than in causing harm.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a heroic figure who risked his life to save others.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main theme of Hannah Arendt's book "The Origins of Totalitarianism"?

options.label: A
options.text: The rise of totalitarianism in Germany was a unique event.

options.label: B
options.text: The decline of critical thinking and the rise of isolation were key factors in the emergence of totalitarianism.

options.label: C
options.text: The Holocaust was a result of a conspiracy between the Nazi regime and other European countries.

options.label: D
options.text: The fall of the Berlin Wall marked the end of totalitarianism in Germany.

multiple-choice.question: What did Hannah Arendt mean by the term "banality of evil"?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that evil is a complex and multifaceted phenomenon.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that evil is a result of a unique combination of circumstances.

options.label: C

title: Does math have a major flaw? - Jacqueline Doan and Alex Kazachek

multiple-choice.question: What is the Banach-Tarski paradox?

options.label: A
options.text: A mathematical result that appears to defy the laws of physics.

options.label: B
options.text: A flawless proof based on axioms.

options.label: C
options.text: A theorem that is only applicable in certain mathematical contexts.

options.label: D
options.text: A paradox that has been disproven by mathematicians.

multiple-choice.question: What are axioms in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: Basic statements declared to be true and used to make deductions.

options.label: B
options.text: Theorems that have been proven to be true.

options.label: C
options.text: Mathematical concepts that are only applicable to all areas of mathematics.

options.label: D
options.text: Principles that are only applicable in certain mathematical contexts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Axiom of Choice?

options.label: A
options.text: An axiom that allows for choosing elements from sets, even when the elements are indistinguishable.

options.label: B
options.text: An axiom that is only applicable in certain mathematical contexts.

options.label: C
options.text: A theorem that has been proven to be true.

options.label: D
options.text: A principle that is only applicable in certain areas of mathematics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Axiom of Choice in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a load-bearing axiom that is essential for many practical results in mathematics.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a theorem that has been proven to be true.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a principle that is only applicable in certain areas of mathematics.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a mathematical concept that is only applicable in certain mathematical contexts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Banach-Tarski paradox used to demonstrate?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of the Axiom of Choice in mathematics.

options.label: B
options.text: The flaws in the Axiom of Choice.

options.label: C
options.text: The limitations of the Axiom of Choice.

options.label: D
options.text: The relationship between mathematics and reality.

multiple-choice.question: What is the freedom that mathematics gives us?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to model our physical universe using axioms we intuit from our daily experiences.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to venture into abstract mathematical universes and explore arcane geometries and laws.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to communicate with other intelligent beings, such as aliens.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the Banach-Tarski paradox and the Axiom of Choice?

options.label: A
options.text: The Banach-Tarski paradox is a direct result of the Axiom of Choice.

options.label: B
options.text: The Banach-Tarski paradox is a counterexample to the Axiom of Choice.

options.label: C
options.text: The Banach-Tarski paradox is a theorem that has been proven to be true using the Axiom of Choice.

options.label: D
options.text: The Banach-Tarski paradox is a paradox that has been disproven by mathematicians.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Banach-Tarski paradox in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a thought-provoking result that challenges our experience of reality.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a flawless proof based on axioms.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a theorem that has been proven to be true.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a principle that is only applicable in certain areas of mathematics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between mathematics and reality?

options.label: A
options.text: Mathematics is a way to model our physical universe using axioms we intuit from our daily experiences.

options.label: B
options.text: Mathematics is a way to venture into abstract mathematical universes and explore arcane geometries and laws.

options.label: C
options.text: Mathematics is a way to communicate with other intelligent beings, such as aliens.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the Banach-Tarski paradox?

options.label: A
options.text: The paradox arises when a mathematician, following Banach and Tarski's proof, uses the Axiom of Choice to construct two identical copies of an original ball from five precise sections.

options.label: B
options.text: The paradox arises when a mathematician, following Banach and Tarski's proof, uses the Axiom of Choice to construct a single copy of an original ball from five precise sections.

options.label: C
options.text: The paradox arises when a mathematician, following Banach and Tarski's proof, uses the Axiom of Choice to construct a single copy of an original ball from three precise sections.

options.label: D
options.text: The paradox arises when a mathematician, following Banach and Tarski's proof, uses the Axiom of Choice to construct a single copy of an original ball from two precise sections.

options.label: C
options.text: To ensure that wealth inequalities are never acceptable

options.label: D
options.text: To ensure that wealth inequalities are always acceptable

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of Rawls' "property owning democracy"?

options.label: A
options.text: A system where property is owned by the government

options.label: B
options.text: A system where property is owned by individuals

options.label: C
options.text: A system where property is owned by the community

options.label: D
options.text: A system where property is owned by the state

title: How to prevent political corruption - Stephanie Honchell Smith

multiple-choice.question: What is corruption, and what can be done to combat it?

options.label: A
options.text: Corruption is a misuse of power for personal gain, and it can be combated by increasing punishment for corrupt behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: Corruption is a misuse of power for personal gain, and it can be combated by increasing transparency and accountability.

options.label: C
options.text: Corruption is a misuse of power for personal gain, and it can be combated by ignoring the issue altogether.

options.label: D
options.text: Corruption is a misuse of power for personal gain, and it can be combated by relying solely on laws to set a high price for corrupt behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of corruption in ancient Greece?

options.label: A
options.text: The Spartans bribing the priestesses at Delphi to deliver false prophecies.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenians bribing the priestesses at Delphi to deliver false prophecies.

options.label: C
options.text: The Alcmaeonid family bribing the priestesses at Delphi to deliver false prophecies.

options.label: D
options.text: The Spartans and Athenians working together to deliver false prophecies.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of corruption in modern-day politics?

options.label: A
options.text: A city clerk accepting bribes in exchange for issuing permits.

options.label: B
options.text: A mayor appointing a campaign donor to an influential position.

options.label: C
options.text: A politician accepting a bribe from a foreign government.

options.label: D
options.text: A politician refusing a bribe from a foreign government.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of corruption in the Baltimore Police Department?

options.label: A
options.text: Officers planting evidence and robbing citizens during traffic stops.

options.label: B
options.text: Officers not following protocol during traffic stops.

options.label: C
options.text: Officers not wearing uniforms during traffic stops.

options.label: D
options.text: Officers not using sirens during traffic stops.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a government building public trust through transparency?

options.label: A
options.text: The government of South Africa building public trust through transparency.

options.label: B
options.text: The government of Botswana building public trust through transparency.

options.label: C
options.text: The government of Denmark building public trust through transparency.

options.label: D
options.text: The government of the United States building public trust through transparency.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a citizen standing up against corruption?

options.label: A
options.text: Mcebisi Jonas refusing the Gupta family's offer and speaking out against corruption.

options.label: B
options.text: A citizen reporting a corrupt official to the authorities.

options.label: C
options.text: A citizen not reporting a corrupt official to the authorities.

options.label: D
options.text: A citizen bribing a corrupt official.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of corruption on a nation's economy?

options.label: A
options.text: Corruption can lead to a strong economy.

options.label: B
options.text: Corruption can lead to a weak economy.

options.label: C
options.text: Corruption has no effect on a nation's economy.

options.label: D
options.text: Corruption can lead to a stable economy.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a government responding openly, quickly, and decisively to corruption?

options.label: A
options.text: The government of South Africa responding openly, quickly, and decisively to corruption.

options.label: B
options.text: The government of Botswana responding openly, quickly, and decisively to corruption.

options.label: C
options.text: The government of Denmark responding openly, quickly, and decisively to corruption.

options.label: D
options.text: The government of the United States responding openly, quickly, and decisively to corruption.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a citizen using their civic voice to demand accountability and transparency from their leaders?

options.label: A
options.text: A citizen voting out a corrupt official.

options.label: B
options.text: A citizen not voting out a corrupt official.

options.label: C
options.text: A citizen bribing a corrupt official.

options.label: D
options.text: A citizen ignoring a corrupt official.

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of transparency in combating corruption?

options.label: A
options.text: Transparency is not important in combating corruption.

options.label: B
options.text: Transparency is somewhat important in combating corruption.

options.label: C
options.text: Transparency is very important in combating corruption.

options.label: D
options.text: Transparency is crucial in combating corruption.
